In Sudan, authorities had announced on 17th of June the extension Khartoum curfew 15:00 to 06:00 (local time) until 29th of June. 

 UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until 18th of June, it has been extended to June 29th.

description: Sudan’s Security and Defence Council chaired by the President of the Sovereign Council, Lt Gen Abdelfattah El Burhan, declared a state of health emergency in Sudan on 16th of March to counter the emerging coronavirus.

In Sudan, on 15th of February, Sarah Abdel Azim, undersecretary of the Federal Ministry of Health have confirmed that  Khartoum airport, rooms for sanitary isolation are being prepared, and the number of health personnel working in the airport, as well as networking with border states and monitoring their conditions. Also, the Federal Ministry of Health has raised level of alert and control at Khartoum Airport to the maximum degree, activated the thermal surveillance, as well as preparing a health declaration form at Khartoum Airport for arrivals from all over the world.
On 12th March 2020, Sudan government closed its land border with Egypt.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 12th March 2020, Sudan government advised Sudanese nationals against travelling to China, Iran, Italy, Spain, Japan and Egypt.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 12th March 2020, Sudan government suspended issuance of visas to nationals of China, Iran, Italy, Spain, Japan and Egypt
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 16th March 2020, Sudan government closed Khartoum Airport for all commercial flights while only permitting the continued operation of scheduled cargo flights and humanitarian flights.

Sudan's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) announced on Thursday, July 9, that Khartoum International Airport (KRT) has reopened for passenger flights from Egypt, Turkey, and the United Arab Emirates (UAE). All passengers arriving at the airport should follow Health Ministry guidelines. UPDATE: The original policy banned commercial flights from all around the world, now it has flights from and to UAE, Egypt and Turkey are allowed to resume.

On 16th March 2020, Sudan government closed Khartoum Airport for all commercial flights. However,  Sudan’s Civil Aviation Authority reportedly announced on 20th of April that it has extended a ban on domestic and international flights until at least 20th of May 2020, while only permitting the continued operation of scheduled cargo flights and humanitarian flights.

in Sudan, Sudan’s Civil Aviation Authority has decided to briefly re-open Khartoum airport to air traffic for 48 hours, effective on 19th of March evening, to enable Sudanese stranded abroad by coronavirus (Covid-19) travel restrictions to return home, and foreigners to leave.
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Sudan. the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 25th of March the closure of airport and land borders.

Sudanese state media reports that airports will remain closed until May 31 to contain COVID-19; follow government directives. UPDATE: The original policy was set to 20th of May 2020, it has been extended to May 31 2020.

Khartoum International Airport (KRT) is closed for entry and exit until 14 June 2020. This excludes scheduled cargo flights; humanitarian aid and technical and humanitarian support flights; flights of companies operating in the oil fields; and evacuation flights for foreign nationals. UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until 31st of May, it is now extended until 14th of June.

Sudanese authorities extend international and domestic flight suspension until June 28; confirm travel itineraries. UPDATE: The original policy was set until 31st of May, it is now extended until June 28.

State media reported on Saturday, June 27, that the Sudan Civil Aviation Authority has further extended the closure of Khartoum's International Airport (KRT) until at least 02:00 (local time) on July 12 due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. Flights carrying cargo, humanitarian aid, oil workers, or repatriating foreigners continue to be exempt from this measure.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Authorities extend closure of Khartoum International Airport until July 12; follow government directives
 UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until 28th of June, it has been now extended to July 12 2020.

In Sudan, Sudan's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) announced on Thursday, July 9, that Khartoum International Airport (KRT) that flights to Sudan are suspended until 10 October 2020. - This does not apply to flights arriving from Egypt, Turkey or United Arab Emirates.
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Sudan, Sudan's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) announced on Thursday, July 9, that Khartoum International Airport (KRT) has reopened for passenger flights from Egypt, Turkey, and the United Arab Emirates (UAE). All passengers arriving at the airport should follow Health Ministry guidelines, while Sudanese nationals or expats will have to go through medical examinations. Nationals of Sudan and passengers of Sudanese origin are subject to medical screening. Passengers must have a medical certificate with a negative Coronavirus (COVID-19) PCR test result issued at most 96 hours before arrival.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Sudan, on 16th of March,  disease surveillance measures have been put in place with daily zero reporting activated at 10 entry points to Sudan in Northern, Red Sea, Khartoum, Kassala, Gedaref and West Darfur states; and at seaports, airports and ground crossings.

In Sudan, two isolation centres have been created to treat COVID-19 patients in Sudan. The isolation centre in the Khartoum Teaching Hospital has 37 beds and up to eight ICU beds. The isolation centre located at a trauma centre in south Khartoum has a capacity for 80 beds.
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: In Sudan, the Sudanese government has created military hospitals in Khartoum and in the states are to act as centres for shelter and treatment.
In Sudan, the authorities of South Kordofan state have announced on 5th of April 2020 the distribution of 1000 protective wearing masks to homeless children.

In Sudan, in Khartoum State as on 18th of March borders with neighbouring states have been closed, with the exception for commercial vehicles carrying strategic commodities such as food, medicines and fuel etc.

description: On 20th March 2020, Sudan government suspended all long-haul bus services between cities and states from 18:00.

description: On Sunday, April 12, Sudanese authorities announced a ban on domestic travel to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the country. As such, private and commercial passenger vehicles will be prohibited from traveling between cities and states, effective immediately.
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: In Sudan, in North Kordofan State has closed its borders on 18th of April with other states and has deployed police and security forces at entry points.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Sudan, the White Nile state governor instructed the closure of the borders with the neighbouring states on 22nd of April.

In Sudan, on 23rd of April the Red Sea state in eastern Sudan closed its borders with other states. Ambulances and lorries carrying goods are excluded from the measures. Entry to the state is permitted only after conducting a medical examination of the driver and assistant(s) and sterilisation of the vehicle.

In Sudan, on 24th of April, the acting governor of North Darfur, Maj Gen Malik Khojali, issued a decree shutting down all entrances and exits of the capital El Fasher in order to prevent a coronavirus outbreak. Vehicles that carry strategic goods such as fuel, food, vegetables and fruits are exempted, if they have a permit from the authorities.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Sudan, the governor of El Gedaref, Maj Gen Nasreldin Ahmed issued on 24th of April a decision to close down all the entrances with the bordering countries and neighbouring cities or localities.

In Sudan, the governor of the Red Sea state, Maj Gen Hafiz El Taj decided to ban public or private vehicles can enter the state, except for ambulances and trucks that transport good starting on 25th of April 2020

description: In Sudan, El Gezira, south of Khartoum, will block all entrances to the state on 26th of April 2020.

in Sudan, in South Darfur, governor Maj Gen Hashim Mahmoud decided on 26th of April that traffic to the neighbouring states and from one locality to another will be forbidden. There will be legal consequences for those who violates the new measures. “Not less than three months imprisonment or a fine of SDG 10,000 ($182)* or both,”, the governor's statement read.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 30th of April that citizens are prevented from traveling to White Nile State and  those coming from White Nile State are not allowed to enter South Kordofan. In addition, roads leading to White Nile is closed. It is permitted to travel to the White Nile for emergency cases, which are determined by the doctor or the local security committee after obtaining a valid approval and passage permit from the local security committee.

description: In Sudan, on 14 March, the Government of Sudan announced that government and private institutions should take measures to reduce congestion in the workplace.
In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan announced on 23rd of March the closure of all hookah shops in all markets and neighbourhoods.
In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 1st of April the closure of all markets, especially the so-called weekly markets and hold its activities until further notice.
In Sudan, in North Kordufan, hookah shops (shisha shops) in public areas with reduced congestion in the markets are closed starting on 18th of April 2020.
In Sudan, the White Nile state governor instructed the closure all markets and shops for the coming two weeks starting from 22nd of April, with the exception of pharmacies and shops selling food.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Sudan, El Dindir locality in Sennar announced the closure of all markets for ten days starting on 24th of April. Employees of the locality are granted a paid leave.
In Sudan, on 24th of April, the acting governor of North Darfur, Maj Gen Malik Khojali announced the closure of all markets.
In Sudan, the government of El Gezira decided that starting on 26th of April the markets must close at 1 pm each day, and street vendors are banned.

In Sudan, in South Darfur, governor Maj Gen Hashim Mahmoud decided  on 26th of April the closure of all major markets and shops in Nyala will be closed as on 27th of April 2020 for 10 days, except for essential services such as pharmacies, bakeries, shops selling food, and health care. There will be legal consequences for those who violates the new measures. “Not less than three months imprisonment or a fine of SDG 10,000 ($182)* or both,”, the governor's statement read.

type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: In Sudan, Sudanese authorities announced on Monday, April 13, that a three-week lockdown in Khartoum and Omdurman will come into effect on Saturday, April 18, after ten cases of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) were confirmed in the country. description: In Sudan, in South Darfur, governor Maj Gen Hashim Mahmoud decided on 26th of April that public services will be provided from 8 am until 12 am,” the governor said in a statement. There will be legal consequences for those who violates the new measures. “Not less than three months imprisonment or a fine of SDG 10,000 ($182)* or both,”, the governor's statement read.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On 12th March 2020, Sudan government discouraged mass gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 14th March 2020, the government of Sudan cautioned against social/public gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: in Sudan, in Khartoum State,  as of 18th of March all gatherings have been banned including weddings and Ramadan iftars.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan announced on 23rd of March 2020, that all gatherings have been banned including all celebrations, queues in front of bakeries and fuel stations and prevent unnecessary gatherings that exceed more than 50 people.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 1st of April the closure of various gathering places.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, Sudanese authorities announced on Monday, April 13, that a three-week lockdown in Khartoum and Omdurman will come into effect on Saturday, April 18 where prayers in mosques and church services have been suspended in Khartoum state during the three-week lockdown period.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: In Sudan, North Kordofan State it was announced on 18th of April the closure of gatherings in clubs, weddings, graduations, community gatherings and concerts.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 20th March 2020, all mass gatherings including religious celebrations were banned. All sports and cafes were closed. UPDATE: On 20th March 2020, Sudan government banned all mass gatherings, including religious celebrations. All sports venues and cafes were closed. This enhanced the caution against social/public gatherings issued on 14th March 2020..
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Sudan, On 20th March 2020, all mass gatherings including religious celebrations were banned. All sports and cafes were closed.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, in a press conference in Nyala on 23rd of April, the governor of South Darfur urged the people in the state to prevent gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, on 24th of April, the acting governor of North Darfur, Maj Gen Malik Khojali decided to ban collective breaking of the Ramadan fast in squares and streets in all localities of North Darfur. The tarawih prayers, traditionally performed in mosques during Ramadan in the evening should be performed at home.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Sudan, on 27th of April 2020, the executive director of the municipality of El Gedaref clarified that all public gatherings are prohibited including Ramadan public prayers (taraweeh) in mosques in the city.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: in Sudan, the Committee of COVID-19 Emergency in South Kordofan have announced on 30th of April the ban of gatherings and parties except after obtaining approval from the police.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 23rd of March that public transportation and busses need apply social distancing such as limited number of seats.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: In Sudan, the governor of South Kordofan have announced on 23rd of March that public transportation and busses need apply social distancing such as limited number of seats.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: In Sudan, In Sudan, on 24th of April, the acting governor of North Darfur, Maj Gen Malik Khojali instructed imams to perform prayers in the open air, in the courtyards of the mosques, where adequete space between worshipers can be guarenteed to prevent crowding.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
